member.summary: Possible options to apply the alignment algorithm.

member.name: P:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.AlignmentParameters.DifferentRateAllowed
member.summary: If this option is 'true':If the XStep are not equal between the data to align and the date to match, the rate will be adapted and the alignment is allowed. If this option is false: in the same situation than above, the alignement is not done and the user is informed of the problem.

member.name: P:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.AlignmentParameters.RemoveAdditionalPoints
member.summary: If this option is 'true': If after restriction to the common X-axis range the 2 data have a gap of a few points (different number of points), we remove these additional points in the data that has additional points. If this option is 'false': in the same situation than above, the data that has less points if filled with zero values.

member.name: P:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.AlignmentParameters.ChooseSmallestXStep
member.summary: If this option is 'true': the smallest x step (between the data to align and the data to match) is chosen for the alignment on the X-axis. If this option is 'false': the step of the data to match is chosen.

member.name: T:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.DataAlignmentHelper
member.summary: Align the specified data with specified data to match so that the data points have the same x values for both data (alignment on the X axis). This is necessary for performing operation like background subtraction or PearsonCorrelation, etc, that operate only on data aligned on the X axis. After conversion, the data is equidistant, the 2 data (data to align and data to match) have the same XStep, the same XMin, the same number of samples and the same time range.

member.summary: The converted spectrum is equidistant. The smallest X Step is chosen to align the 2 data. If the smallest XStep is the step of the data to align, it will be chosen and the data to match will be adjusted accordingly. If the 2 data (the data to align and the data to match) have a gap of a few points, we remove these additional points in the data that has additional points.

member.summary: If there is a gap between the number of points of the 2 data (few points, generally no more than one point), reduce or fill data.

member.name: M:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.DataAlignmentHelper.RatesAreDifferentAndTimeRangeHasBeenAdapted(Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.IEquidistantData,Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.IData,System.Boolean)

member.name: M:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.DataAlignmentHelper.GetCommonTimeRange(Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.IData,Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.IEquidistantData,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Get the common time range between the data to align and the data to match. The range is rounded to decimal values. The low bound is always greater than or equal to the minimum calculated as double value. The high bound is always less than or equal to the maximum calculated as double value. Therefore, the range is always less than or equal to the 'exact' range.

member.name: M:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.DataAlignmentHelper.FillDataToAlignToMatchData(Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.IEquidistantData,Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.IEquidistantData)
member.summary: If the the data to align (eg the blank) resulting from the alignement (DataOperations.Extract or DataOperations.Spline) have less points than the chromatogram, this method is used to add points to match the chromatogram size. If the XMin are not aligned (XMinDataToAlign > XMinChromato) we will go through this method. Extrapolate at the beginning of the data: only if difference of points at the beginning is 1 or 2 (otherwise the points added are zero values) Extrapolate at the end of the data: only if difference of points at the end is 1 or 2 (otherwise the points added are zero value) Returned data has same size, same XMin ans same XStep as the chromatogram. The scenario that is filled here is the following: during the acquisition, there can be a difference of one or 2 points at the beginning and/or at the end of the blank and the chromatogram. In this case, we need to adjust the blank, to avoid artifact at the beginning or at the end of the corrected sample. If the difference is larger (eg 6 points missing at the begining) we simply fill the data with zero values. On a chemist point of view we do not want to manage this cases.

member.name: M:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.DataAlignmentHelper.ShiftDataToAlignToMatchData(Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.IEquidistantData,Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.IEquidistantData)
member.summary: Shift the data to align (XMin dataToAlgin > XMin dataToMatch) Move Y values from N indices where N is the number of XStep between the 2 XMin, extrapolate the N first values, and remove the N last values (to keep the same size) (if XMinAlign = xMinToMatch + N * XStep => move YValue from N indices)

member.summary:
Does a linear interpolation between data1 and data2 at position t.
f1 = (t2-t)/(t2-t1) f2 = (t-t1)/(t2-t1)
D = f1*D1+f2*D2
The data can be equidistant or / non equidistant
member.returns: returns interpolated data or null if not possible

member.name: M:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.DataOperations.Transform(Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.IData,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Axis)
member.summary: Shifts and scales the data points. Does a linear shift/scale between the 'from' and 'to' points. By specifying two points (d0from and d1from) along the chosen axis and assigning them new values (d0to and d1to) the data for either the X or Y axis is shifted and scaled. When the command is complete, d0from is shifted to d0to, and d1from is shifted to d1to. All other points along the axis are shifted and scaled appropriately to maintain the aspect of the curve. For example d0from:d1from and d0to:d1to define a linear transformation on the data: new value = m Ã— (old value) + b where: m = (d1to - d0to)/(d1from - d0from) b = d1to - m * d1from d0from must not be equal to d1from. d0to must not be equal to d1to.

member.name: M:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.LoessInterpolator.UpdateBandwidthInterval(System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Given an index interval into xval that embraces a certain number of points closest to xval[i-1], update the interval so that it embraces the same number of points closest to xval[i]
member.param: index around the new inteval should be computed

Interval a two-element array {left, right} such that:
(left==0 or xval[i] - xval[left-1] > xval[right] - xval[i])
and also
(right==xval.length-1 or xval[right+1] - xval[i] > xval[i] - xval[left]).

member.name: T:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.CubicSpline
member.summary: Cubic spline interpolation. Call Fit to compute spline coefficients, then Eval to evaluate the spline at other X coordinates.

remarks.para: This is implemented based on the wikipedia article: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spline_interpolation I'm not sure I have the right to include a copy of the article so the equation numbers referenced in comments will end up being wrong at some point.
This is not optimized, and is not MT safe. This can extrapolate off the ends of the splines. You must provide points in X sort order.

member.name: M:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.CubicSpline.GetNextXIndex(System.Double)
member.summary: Find where in xOrig the specified x falls, by simultaneous traverse. This allows xs to be less than x[0] and/or greater than x[n-1]. So allows extrapolation. This keeps state, so requires that x be sorted and xs called in ascending order.

member.name: T:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.TriDiagonalMatrixF
member.summary: A tri-diagonal matrix has non-zero entries only on the main diagonal, the diagonal above the main (super), and the diagonal below the main (sub).

remarks.para: This is based on the wikipedia article: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tridiagonal_matrix_algorithm

The entries in the matrix on a particular row are A[i], B[i], and C[i] where i is the row index. B is the main diagonal, and so for an NxN matrix B is length N and all elements are used. So for row 0, the first two values are B[0] and C[0]. And for row N-1, the last two values are A[N-1] and B[N-1]. That means that A[0] is not actually on the matrix and is therefore never used, and same with C[N-1].

member.name: F:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.TriDiagonalMatrixF.A
member.summary: The values for the sub-diagonal. A[0] is never used.

member.name: F:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.TriDiagonalMatrixF.B
member.summary: The values for the main diagonal.

member.name: F:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.Math.TriDiagonalMatrixF.C
member.summary: The values for the super-diagonal. C[C.Length-1] is never used.

member.summary: The width and height of this matrix.

member.name: T:Agilent.OpenLab.Framework.DataAccess.CoreTypes.DetectorType
member.summary:
Detector type
Purpose: characterization of signal for different: - (display) units, - response ranges, - processing parameters (integrator event table defaults), - Identification of detector main peak for cross-detector peak correlation in compound identification - ... This is mainly driven by the acquiring detector. But e.g. an MSD can operate either in MS or in MS/MS mode, producing chromatograms or spectra: These require different processing algorithms and parameters, although the detector is the same
Originally modified from QualDataType as defined in \Archer\qual\definitions\methods\QualDAMethod.cs and used for (integrator) parameter specification in \Archer\qual\applogic\applogic\appbusinessmanager.cs Qual application data types to differentiate parameter specifically for given data type.
